On a successful ability check, the spell creates an {@condition invisible} sensor within 10 feet of the target. You can see and hear through the sensor as if you were there. The sensor moves with the target, remaining within 10 feet of it for the duration. A creature that can see {@condition invisible} objects sees the sensor as a luminous orb about the size of your fist.

Instead of targeting a creature, you can also choose a location or object as the target of this spell. The base DC for this is 10 + any of the knowledge and connection modifiers listed above. When you do, the sensor appears at that location and doesn't move.

spell.name: Lightning Bolt

components.m: a bit of fur and a rod of amber, crystal, or glass

entries: A stroke of lightning forming a line 100 feet long and 5 feet wide blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 5d8} lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledamage 5d8|3-9|1d8} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Frost Fingers
entries: Freezing cold blasts from your fingertips in a 30-foot long, 5-foot wide line. Each creature in that area must make a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 2d8} cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The cold freezes nonmagical liquids in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Havoc Blast

m.text: a soul shard, which the spell consumes

entries: You unleash a large, devastating blast of chaotic energy at a creature that you can see within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target, and declare either fire or necrotic damage. If the attack hits, the creature takes {@damage 3d8} damage of the type you chose. This spell scores a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell as a Warlock with access to higher level spells than 1st level, the damage of the spell is increased by {@dice 1d8} and the critical hit range is lowered by 1 for each spell level above 1st.

spell.name: Soulshatter

m.text: a soul shard, which the spell consumes

entries: You load the soul shard used for the spell with arcane magic, and thrust it to cause an explosion on impact. Make a melee spell attack against a creature you can reach. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 4d6} force damage, and is pushed back 10 feet if it is a Large or smaller creature.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell as a Warlock with access to higher level spells than 1st level, the damage of the spell is increased by {@dice 1d6} and the push back distance is increased by 5 feet for each spell level above 1st.

spell.name: Incineration

m.text: a soul shard, which the spell consumes

entries: A line of roaring flame 60 feet long and 5 feet wide originating from you is unleashed from the ground in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 5d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell as a Warlock with access to higher level spells than 2nd level, the damage of the spell is increased by {@dice 1d6} and the width of the line is increased by 5 feet for each spell level above 2nd.

spell.name: Channel Hellfire

m.text: a soul shard, which the spell consumes

entries: A blast of multiple dark, hellish bolts of flame shoot out of your hand towards a designated creature within range, creating a stream of bolts. The target creature must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 8d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

On each of your following turns for the duration of the spell, you can use a bonus action to continue shooting bolts at the target through the stream with a bonus action. The bolts fired on subsequent turns with a bonus action deal {@damage 3d6} fire damage, with the same Dexterity saving throw.
The spell ends if you do not continue it each turn with a bonus action. The spell also ends if the target dies, if it is ever outside the spell's range, or if it has total cover from you.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell as a Warlock with access to higher level spells than 3rd level, both the initial damage and the subsequent damage of the spell is increased by {@dice 1d6} for each spell level above 3rd.

spell.name: Curse of Doom

m.text: a soul shard, which the spell consumes

entries: You attempt to place a powerful curse on a creature that you can see within range. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is cursed with impending doom. Once the target creature has had two turns after being cursed, at the end of the second turn the creature takes {@damage 11d6} necrotic damage, and the curse ends.
A {@spell Remove Curse|farover} cast on the target harmlessly ends this spell.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell as a Warlock with access to higher level spells than 3rd level, the damage of the spell is increased by {@dice 1d6} and the range of the spell is increased by 20 feet for each spell level above 3rd.

spell.name: Cataclysm

m.text: a soul shard, which the spell consumes

entries: You create a storm of fire and destruction in an area, which is momentarily bombarded by molten stones and flames. Each creature in a 20-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on a point you choose must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 5d6} fire damage and {@damage 5d6} bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell as a Warlock with access to higher level spells than 4th level, both the fire and bludgeoning damage is increased by {@dice 1d6}, the radius of the cylinder is increased by 5 feet, and the height of the cylinder is increased by 10 feet for each spell level above 4th.

spell.name: Impending Flame

m.text: a soul shard, which the spell consumes

entries: You unleash a small blast of fire which increases in size as it flies toward a creature of your choice within range. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 9d6} fire damage, which is increased by {@dice 1d6} for every 30 feet between you and the target of the spell, up to {@dice 4d6} more at exactly 120 feet. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell as a Warlock with access to higher level spells than 4th level, the range of the spell is increased by 30 feet for each spell level above 4th, thus also increasing the maximum damage of the spell by {@dice 1d6}.

spell.name: Cascading Soul Strike

m.text: a soul shard, which the spell consumes

entries: You harness the power of the soul shard used for the casting of this spell, and transform it into a dark, ethereal weapon which you propel at a target within range. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw as the ethereal weapon rips into the creatures body, ravaging it's mind.

On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 8d8} psychic damage, and the ethereal weapon can cascade onward to a new target of your choice within 30 feet of the original target. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage, and the weapon does not fly on to attack a new target. If the creature dies from the damage, the weapon can attack a new target regardless of the result of the saving throw.

Each time the weapon flies to attack a new target after the original, the effect of the attack is the same, but the amount of dice rolled for the psychic damage is halved each time (rounded down). The weapon created by the spell can attack the same creature multiple times, and it can keep making attacks as long as it has dice remaining to deal damage with.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell as a Warlock with access to higher level spells than 5th level, the initial damage of the ethereal weapon is increased by {@dice 1d8} and the range of the cascading hits is increased by 10 feet for each spell level above 5th.

spell.name: Curse of Agony

m.text: a soul shard, which the spell consumes

entries: You attempt to place a powerful curse on a creature that you can see within range. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a successful save, the spell ends. On a failed save, the target is cursed with excruciating pain, taking {@damage 1d8} necrotic damage, which increases over time. As long as you maintain concentration on the spell, the target creature automatically suffers damage at the end of each of its turns. The damage of the curse increases by {@dice 1d8} every time the target suffers damage after the first time.

The curse can last for a maximum of 5 rounds, and deal damage 5 times, after which it ends. If the target of the curse dies before the 5 rounds have passed, you can use your action on your turn to attempt to continue the curse on a different target. The new target must make the same saving throw, and on a failed save, the curse and it's progression is moved to the new target, dealing it's damage and maintaining it's damage progression on the new target.
A {@spell Remove Curse|farover} cast on the target ends this spell.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell as a Warlock with access to higher level spells than 5th level, the duration of the spell is increased by 1 round for each spell level above 5th.

items: When you fall below 25% hit points, you become wounded.
When you are wounded, you gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}.
This {@condition exhaustion} level can only be lost by removing the wounded condition, which is done by healing to at least 25% hit points.

table.name: Aging Effects
intro: Every humanoid creature ages with time, and reaches new age classes as explained below. The natural lifespan of a creature is, depending on their race, a low flat amount plus a variable dice roll, resulting on average with a base venerable age. Only the DM knows this number. Characters living their final natural years will know their end is soon upon them.
{@bold {@italic Cumulative Effects}}: Each time a character reaches a new age class, apply the following cumulative effect to the characters stats: -1 to Con; -1 to Str/Dex; +1 to Int/Wis

optionalfeature.name: Brace
entries: As a bonus action, you can ready an attack. Choose a creature you can see that is at least 20 feet away from you. If that creature moves within your weapon's reach on its next turn, you can make a melee attack against it with your braced weapon as a reaction. You can't use this ability if the creature used the Disengage action before moving.

optionalfeature.name: Bleed
entries: Critical hits scored deal extra damage at the start of the creature's next turn equal to the modifier of the ability score used to make the attack.

optionalfeature.name: Cleave
entries: When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points, any excess damage can carry over to another creature within your reach, if the original attack roll hits them.

optionalfeature.name: Nonlethal
entries: You can cause a target to fall unconscious with a melee attack if you choose to, instead of it outright dying or bleeding out.

optionalfeature.name: Parry
entries: As a reaction to being hit by a melee attack with a weapon, you can reduce Bludgeoning, Piercing or Slashing damage taken by your proficiency bonus.

optionalfeature.name: Seize
entries: Immediately after you hit a creature, you can attempt to grapple it with the weapon as a bonus action. If you grapple a creature with a Seize weapon, you can't make attacks with the weapon, and you must keep a hand on it to keep the creature grappled. The grappled creature can make a contested Athletics or Acrobatics check to free itself.

optionalfeature.name: Sunder
entries: When you roll a 20 on your attack roll against a creature, you roll an additional effect from the {@table sunder table|farover}.

optionalfeature.name: Wallop
entries: When you roll a 20 on your attack roll against a size Large or smaller creature, the target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be stunned until the end of their next turn, or until they take any damage. DC = 10 + your proficiency bonus.

optionalfeature.name: Bola
entries: A Large or smaller creature hit by a bola is knocked prone and grappled by it until it is freed. A bola has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to free itself or another creature within its reach. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the bola (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net.

optionalfeature.name: Dagger
entries: Daggers deal double damage to unconscious creatures.

optionalfeature.name: Flail/Heavy Flail
entries: You can make a grapple attack with a flail in your hand. If you grapple a creature with a flail, you can't make attacks with it, and you must keep a hand on the flail to keep the creature grappled. As usual, the grappled creature can make a contested Athletics or Acrobatics check to free themselves.

optionalfeature.name: Greatbow
entries: Greatbows take both great strength and accuracy to wield effectively. The arrows shot from the greatbow are powerful, but the bow itself is so large, that it is impractical. Greatbows use your Strength modifier for attack rolls, and attack rolls with the greatbow are made at disadvantage. Greatbows use both your Strength and Dexterity modifier for damage rolls.
Greatbows have a minimum Strength requirement of 13.

optionalfeature.name: Lance
entries: You have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.

optionalfeature.name: Net
entries: A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is restrained until it is freed. A net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to make a DC 10 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net.

optionalfeature.name: Trident
entries: As a bonus action after you successfully hit a creature with a trident, you can make shove attack. This shove attack can only be used to move the target 5 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Light Shield
entries: {@bold {@italic Block}}. When another creature hits you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to raise your light shield and add +3 to your AC against that attack.
A light shield can be equipped or unequipped with a free item interaction, instead of an action.

optionalfeature.name: Heavy Shield
entries: {@bold {@italic Block}}. When another creature hits either you or an ally of yours within 5 ft. of you with either a melee attack or a ranged weapon attack, you can use your reaction to raise your heavy shield and add +2 to either your AC or your ally's AC against that attack.

fluff.name: The Ranger
entries: Warriors of the wilderness, rangers specialize in hunting the monsters that threaten the edges of civilization: rampaging beasts and monstrosities, terrible giants, and deadly dragons. They learn to track their quarry as a predator does, moving stealthily through the wilds and hiding themselves in brush and rubble. Rangers focus their combat training on techniques that are particularly useful against their specific favored foes.

Thanks to their familiarity with the wilds, rangers acquire the ability to cast spells that harness natures power, much as a druid does. Their spells, like their combat abilities, emphasize speed, stealth, and the hunt. A rangers talents and abilities are honed with deadly focus on the grim task of protecting the borderlands.

As masters of the art of ranged combat, rangers excel especially with ammunition weapons in their hands, but they can hold their own in closer quarters when a foe gets too close as well. Being trained marksmen, they are capable of sharpshooting feats and techniques that leave witnesses in awe.

Though a ranger might make a living as a hunter, a guide, or a tracker, a rangers true calling is to defend the outskirts of civilization from the ravages of monsters and beasts that press in from the wild.

In some places, rangers gather in secretive orders or join forces with druidic circles. Many rangers, though, are independent almost to a fault, knowing that, when a dragon or a band of orcs attacks, a ranger might be the first, and possibly the last, line of defense.

This fierce independence makes rangers well suited to adventuring, since they are accustomed to life far from the comforts of a dry bed and a hot bath. Faced with city-bred adventurers who grouse and whine about the hardships of the wild, rangers respond with some mixture of amusement, frustration, and compassion. But they quickly learn that other adventurers who can carry their own weight in a fight against civilizations foes are worth any extra burden. Coddled city folk might not know how to feed themselves or find fresh water in the wild, but they make up for it in other ways.

classFeature.name: Favored Enemy
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you have significant experience studying, tracking, and hunting a certain type of enemy encountered in the wilds.
Choose a type of favored enemy: aberrations, beasts, elementals, fey, fiends, monstrosities, oozes, plants, or undead.
You have advantage on Wisdom (Survival) checks to track your favored enemies, as well as on Intelligence checks to recall information about them.

In addition, while you see a creature that is your favored enemy and it is within 120 feet of you, you can use an action to quietly observe and learn the creatures movement speed, its Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution scores, and any immunities it might have.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain one use of it when you finish a short rest, and all uses of it when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Hunter's Mark
entries: At 1st level, you gain the ability to magically mark a creature you can see within 90 feet as your quarry with a bonus action. For 1 hour, you deal an extra {@dice 1d4} damage to the target whenever you hit it with a weapon attack, and you have advantage on any Wisdom (Perception) or Wisdom (Survival) check you make to find it. You can only have one Hunter's Mark active at a time.
The damage of Hunter's Mark is increased to {@dice 1d6} at 9th level, and {@dice 1d8} at 17th level.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to 1 + your Wisdom modifier. If you use this feature against your favored enemy, you do not need to spend a use of it. You regain one use of this feature when you finish a short rest, and all uses of it when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: By the time you reach 2nd level, you have learned to use the magical essence of nature to cast spells, much as a druid does. See chapter 10 of the PHB for the general rules of spellcasting, and page 8 for the ranger {@link spell list|https://5e.tools/spells.html#flstclass:ranger=1,,flstclass:ranger(reworked)=2}.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Ranger table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@link ranger spells|https://5e.tools/spells.html#flstclass:ranger=1,,flstclass:ranger(reworked)=2} of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell animal friendship} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell animal friendship} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know three 1st-level spells of your choice from the ranger {@link spell list|https://5e.tools/spells.html#flstclass:ranger=1,,flstclass:ranger(reworked)=2}.

The Spells Known column of the Ranger table shows when you learn more ranger spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 5th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your ranger spells, since your magic draws on your attunement to nature. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a ranger spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use any weapon made of wood, such as a longbow, as a spellcasting focus for your ranger spells.

classFeature.name: Steady Aim
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, you can give yourself advantage on your first ranged attack roll of the turn by not using any movement during that turn. You can do this only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you give yourself advantage, your speed is 0 until the end of the current turn.

classFeature.name: Natural Explorer
entries: At 3rd level, you become adept at navigating the natural world, and you react with swift and decisive action when attacked. This grants you the following benefits in combat and when travelling for an hour or more:

As masters of the art of ranged combat, rangers excel especially with ammunition weapons in their hands, but they can hold their own in closer quarters when a foe gets too close as well. Being trained marksmen, they are capable of sharpshooting feats and techniques that leave witnesses in awe.

items: You have advantage on initiative rolls.
On your first turn during combat, you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures that have not yet acted.
Your group can't become lost except by magical means.
Even when you are engaged in another activity while traveling (such as navigating or tracking), you remain alert to danger.
If you are traveling alone, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.
When you forage, you find twice as much food as you normally would.
While tracking other creatures, you also learn their exact number, their sizes, and how long ago they passed through the area.

entries: In addition, you have an innate ability to communicate with beasts, and they recognize you as a kindred spirit. Through sounds and gestures, you can communicate simple ideas to a beast as an action, and can read its basic mood and intent. You learn its emotional state, whether it is affected by magic of any sort, its short-term needs (such as food or safety), and actions you can take (if any) to persuade it to not attack.
You cannot use this ability against a creature that you have attacked within the past 10 minutes.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave
entries: At 3rd level, you choose to emulate the ideals and training of a ranger conclave from the list of available conclaves on page 5. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 11th, and 15th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Shot Mastery
entries: At 5th level, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn, you can attack twice, instead of once.

In addition, your expertise with missile weapons unlocks an advanced tier of shot options for you. Whenever you take the Attack action on your turn with a ranged weapon, you can make one special weapon attack, instead of attacking twice.

When making one of these special weapon attacks, any additional damage you might deal from spells, other features, or other sources as part of the attack can only apply to one creature hit. You have four choices of special attacks:

entries.name: Curving Shot
entries: When making a curving shot, make an attack roll against a target you can see or at a square in a location you are aware of within range, regardless of cover. As long as there is a path for the projectile, and the target doesn't have full cover from all sides, your shot can travel around cover and hit your target. The range of your weapon for this shot is halved, as are any long range disadvantages that apply to your weapon. Your attack roll ignores any AC cover benefits that aren't full cover.

entries.name: Multi Shot
entries: When making a multi shot, you load your weapon with up to four ammunition for a single shot that can hit multiple enemies in front of you. Make an attack roll with your weapon as normal. The attack roll you make can hit up to four creatures of your choice inside a 40-foot cone originating from you, as long as they are not behind any cover at all, including that from other creatures. If a creature is behind any cover at all, the attack misses against that target.

entries.name: Piercing Shot
entries: When making a piercing shot, make an attack roll as normal against an enemy in range. Regardless of if the attack hits the target or not, the projectile pierces or flies past the enemy, and it can hit up to 3 additional creatures if they are inside a 5-foot wide line connecting from you, through the initial target that was attacked, to them. The same attack roll is used for each target. Even if the attack roll misses a target, the projectile continues flying until it hits 4 creatures in total, or terrain, or an object. The projectile can not fly further than the range of your weapon, and long range disadvantages apply as normal.

entries.name: Volley Shot
entries: When making a volley shot, you load your weapon with up to four ammunition for a volley strike from the sky within range. Make one weapon attack as normal. The range of your weapon for this shot is halved, as are any long range disadvantages that apply to your weapon. Your attack can then hit up to four targets within 5 feet of a point you shoot at.

classFeature.name: Greater Favored Enemy
entries: At 6th level, you are ready to adopt a second favored enemy, and the knowledge you have of your favored enemies is expanded. Choose one additional type of favored enemy. This can be any type of creature, except humanoids.

You also gain added benefits when it comes to interacting with your favored enemies. When using an action to quietly observe a favored enemy, you also learn its natural or unarmored AC, its current hit points, and any resistances or vulnerabilities it might have.
In addition, when you attack a favored enemy that is affected by your Hunter's Mark feature, the damage die of the mark increases by one die size.

classFeature.name: Primeval Awareness
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can attune your senses to determine if any of your favored enemies lurk nearby. By spending 1 uninterrupted minute in concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell), you can sense whether any of your favored enemies are present within 5 miles of you. This feature reveals which of your favored enemies are present, their numbers, and the creatures' general direction and distance (in miles) from you.
If there are multiple groups of your favored enemies within range, you learn this information for each group.
You can use this feature an amount of times equal to your Wisdom modifier, and you restore all uses of it on a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Fleet of Foot
entries: Beginning at 8th level, you can use the Dash action as a bonus action on your turn, and when you do so, you ignore difficult terrain for the rest of your turn.

classFeature.name: Survival Expert
entries: At 9th level, you gain expertise in the Survival skill, doubling your proficiency bonus. If you are not proficient in Survival, you instead gain proficiency.

classFeature.name: Point-Blank Maneuverability
entries: Starting at 10th-level, you can no longer have disadvantage on ranged attacks while a hostile creature is within 5 feet of you.
Additionally, if you attack a creature on your turn, you don't provoke opportunity attacks from that creature for the rest of the turn. This feature can only affect one enemy creature per turn.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave Feature
entries: At 11th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Further Favored Enemies
entries: When you reach 13th level, you can choose a third type of favored enemy. This favored enemy can be any type of creature, except humanoids.

classFeature.name: Cloak of Nature
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can spend 1 minute creating an effective camouflage for yourself. You must have access to fresh mud, dirt, plants, soot, and other naturally occurring materials with which to create your camouflage.

Once you are camouflaged in this way, you are practically invisible. As long as you don't take any damage and don't move more than 15 feet per round, you will remain invisible to others. Otherwise, this invisibility lasts until you finish a short rest. Any spells or effects that reveal invisible creatures will still reveal you.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave Feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Feral Senses
entries: At 18th level, you gain preternatural senses that help you fight creatures you can't see. When you attack a creature you can't see, your inability to see it doesn't impose disadvantage on your attack rolls against it. You are also aware of the location of any invisible creature within 30 feet of you, provided that the creature isn't hidden from you and you aren't blinded or deafened.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Foe Slayer
entries: At 20th level, you become an unparalleled hunter. When you roll initiative at the beginning of combat and have no uses of Hunter's Mark left, you regain one use.

Additionally, once on each of your turns, you can add your Wisdom modifier to the attack roll or the damage roll of an attack you make. You can choose to use this feature before or after the roll, but before any effects of the roll are applied.
